subject: Re: [junit] Re: A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: ... I agree, and on re-reading the statement, I can see how one could interpret it to be much more nasty than I intended it. I apologize to Phil. I did not
messageBody:
On 2008-06-14, at 20:32 , Mark Levison wrote:

> On Fri, Jun 13, 2008 at 11:14 PM, J. B. Rainsberger
> <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> >
> > On 2008-06-09, at 23:59 , Phil Surette wrote:
> >
> > > The log is not important. Feel free to skip it.
> > >
> > > If, however, you find yourself a little mystified about your
> > > test case's behaviour, you have the option of turning on
> > > the log to get another view on what the test case is doing.
> > > Alternately you could run the test in a debugger. Or you could
> > > start writing a bunch of hand-crafted logging statements since
> > > logging is sometimes more effective than debugging.
> > > But in some cases the assertion log would already be logging what
> > > you need to know without your having to write those statements.
> > >
> > > It's just another tool that is sometimes useful. Debuggers
> > > are important, but you don't have to use them.
> > >
> > ...or you could write smaller, more focused tests and learn
> something
> > about design.
>
> Is this a fair statement to make? You've never met Phil nor have you
> seen any of his test cases. You've no idea if he writes small focused
> tests or not.
>
> I think we can all learn to do a better job but I don't think this
> sort of reply serves either Phil or you well. Perhaps if this
> discussion were face to face that would have helped us all.
>
I agree, and on re-reading the statement, I can see how one could
interpret it to be much more nasty than I intended it. I apologize to
Phil. I did not mean the comment to be nasty, but rather to offer an
alternative in a nice, neutral, non-judgmental tone of voice. Honest.

Phil, you might already know a bunch about design, you might have
relatively little experience. Either way, if you have not experienced
the effect of writing small, focused tests, I recommend it. You will
certainly learn something about design and you might find you don't
much want to log assertions anymore.

I meant to say that the first time.
